If by April 15, 2017, a House of Congress has not agreed to a concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2018, the payroll administrator shall hold Members of Congress' compensation in escrow until a resolution is reached. The period for holding salaries begins on April 16, 2017, and ends when an agreement is made. The payroll administrator will withhold Members of Congress' compensation if a budget resolution for fiscal year 2018 is not agreed upon by a certain date or by the end of the One Hundred Fifteenth Congress. Amounts held in escrow will have the same withholding and remittance procedures as regular payments. At the end of the Congress, the withheld amounts will be released to ensure compliance with the twenty-seventh amendment. The payroll administrator of a House of Congress must release any remaining amounts in an escrow account to Members of Congress at the end of the One Hundred Fifteenth Congress. The Secretary of the Treasury will assist in carrying out this section. The term "Member of Congress" includes Delegates and Resident Commissioners. The "payroll administrator" is defined as the administrator of a House of Congress. The administrator of a House of Congress, in the House of Representatives, is the Chief Administrative Officer or a designated employee, and in the Senate, it is the Secretary or a designated employee of the Office of the Secretary. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF AUTOMATIC PAY ADJUSTMENTS FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Repeals automatic pay adjustments for members of Congress. Effective December 31, 2016.

SEC. 4. PROHIBITING USE OF FUNDS FOR OFFICIAL TRAVEL EXPENSES OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS AND LEGISLATIVE BRANCH EMPLOYEES FOR AIRLINE ACCOMMODATIONS OTHER THAN COACH-CLASS. Prohibits the use of funds for official travel expenses of members of Congress and employees for airline accommodations other than coach-class. Prohibition on using funds for official travel expenses of Members of Congress and legislative branch employees for airline accommodations other than coach-class, with exceptions outlined for specific circumstances. The section prohibits the use of funds for official travel expenses of Members of Congress and legislative branch employees for airline accommodations other than coach-class, with defined exceptions. The term "coach-class accommodations" is clarified as the basic class of airline accommodation, effective from fiscal year 2018 onwards. SEC. 5. 5-YEAR POST-EMPLOYMENT BAN ON LOBBYING BY FORMER MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Former Senators and Members of the House of Representatives are subject to a 5-year post-employment ban on lobbying after leaving office. This includes restrictions on making communications or appearances to influence members or employees of Congress on behalf of others. Former Senators and Members of the House of Representatives are subject to a 5-year post-employment ban on lobbying after leaving office. This includes restrictions on making communications or appearances to influence members or employees of Congress on behalf of others. Any person who is an elected officer of the House of Representatives and knowingly makes any communication to influence a Member, officer, or employee of the House within 1 year after leaving office shall be punished as provided in section 216 of this title. Former elected officers are prohibited from lobbying Congress after leaving office. Any communication made to influence Congress within one year of leaving office will be punished. The amendments apply to individuals leaving office after the enactment of this Act.
